If I could make one point of criticism, if I can be frank on this, there is a tendency in other jurisdictions to do more public-private partnerships in this area. We do not have this here and we are missing out, in a sense, on the public and private sectors getting behind something together. Even though An Garda Síochána is very supportive of all that we do in FraudSMART, there is a political necessity for the Government, through one Minister, to lead out on financial crime. Sometimes we do get caught between the Department of justice and the Department of Finance, if I can be frank. Other countries have a more holistic approach to this. Certainly FraudSMART is our contribution to this and we would like to do an awful lot more.

We would love to do more in schools. It is a very heavy curriculum that everybody wants to get involved in. The case Deputy Timmins referred to in Kerry involved 60 transition year students who became money mules. Every year we have a campaign on money mules and the demographic that we target is students. We run it in September generally, when students are going back to college. We see an increase in students having high costs and they get tempted into money muling. Every year we have a campaign on it to bring awareness. It is primarily on social media, given the audience. We do not expect everyone in the room here to see it but it is targeted directly at the students.

I know there is a limit to what the Banking and Payments Federation can do with its resources but it is certainly something I raised with the Minister for education a few months back, with regard to educating kids in transition year and with regard to transition year programmes becoming much more relevant to real life, such as what we are talking about here today.

The whole question of financial education is a very important issue. I know in the UK it is part of the curriculum. Whether this is the approach here is another matter. This whole question of keeping people safe and making sure they are aware of financial crime could fit very neatly into a wider financial education. At one level, are we the people to do this, given the fact we represent the industry? We lobby for the industry. This is why I would make the call to the committee to consider a much wider public-private partnership piece which would involve us, the credit institutions directly and the State in doing more together. It is this holistic piece. I am aware that in other countries there are particular Ministers with responsibility for financial crime because it does fit into a number of different Departments. It is something we could learn from.
It falls between stools a little bit here.
It has a tendency to do this, yes.

To go back to an old chestnut about people wanting to hear a live voice when they ring, I gave an example earlier of an elderly couple applying for the non-contributory old age pension who could not get anybody at An Post and it is the only bank account they have. They have to send a copy of bank statements as part of means testing but they could not get anyone on the phone for three days and they only get an annual statement. There is a website with a phone number, the same as with the neobanks, but it is about trying to enforce these numbers whereby someone picks up the phone at the other end and people are not sent around the houses.

The point is well made. On occasion people need to speak directly to a human being. Each bank is different in terms of its operating model. The traditional banks in Ireland also use digital, online and apps in the same way that neobanks do. Their model is based on branch banking, online banking and call centres. It is a slightly different model on the neobanking side. Not all neobanks are the same but if they were answering the question they would probably say they have developed a system that uses chatbots to try to make sure they get to the root of the problem and then move on to a live chat for people and, in circumstances where a customer needs direct in-app conversations, this can happen also. It is a different model from the more traditional banks. The traditional banks, if they were here, would say that is their model and how they compete and, equally, the neobanks compete with their model. There are different models but the point is well made. There are occasions when people need to speak and certainly-----
Not everyone uses the Internet.
But, of course, if someone has neobank account they have an app.
Sorry, I mean for the regular banks such as An Post.
Yes, and the point is well made.

How successful are we in tracking down people who use an 087 number to phone someone and tell them their Visa account has been defrauded? I know it is a fraudulent call. I used to get a few from Italy for some reason, which began with 0039. Has there been any success in following up these numbers? Some of them are Irish mobile numbers but they are clearly not based in Ireland.

I will not necessarily speak on whether they have been tracked down, as this would be a matter for An Garda Síochána, but what I can say from our perspective is that ComReg has been working on seven initiatives on prevention. One of them is DNO, which is do not originate, in which our members also participate. To use the example of a call centre, these are numbers that send online messages and never originate calls, so they cannot be used for scam calls. There was another initiative whereby there are international numbers appearing on these calls and we never see Irish numbers any more. This is down to ComReg and the initiatives it has taken. At least it is a little bit of a red flag if people are getting an international number as opposed to an Irish number. This is a huge step. ComReg also recently launched an SMS service whereby people will see if text message comes in and the business has not registered-----
They are untrackeable, though. The numbers that appear on one's phone are untrackeable.
The numbers are being spoofed. If it is an impersonation, they are spoofing a number. It does not originate from that number.
I tried dialling back the Irish mobile-----
You will not be able to.
It is a different person producing it.

I am not an IT expert, but that is all working in the background. I suggest that everybody reports those to An Garda Síochána. Even if somebody has not fallen victim to a scam, it is really important to report this information because gardaí can use it to build a case. There may be another case, and they will always ask us to get that message out there. It may be a missing piece of information.

Ms Davenport referred to the massive amount of data the BPFI gets. It is obviously using AI to figure things out. Does it flag stuff to the authorities, for example, the Department of Social Protection and An Garda Síochána. if it sees suspicious activity relating to accounts?

All suspicious activity has to be reported. That comes under the anti-money laundering regulation. We know that the suspicious transaction reports they have to make under this regulation have tripled in the past number of years. This is why we are very supportive of the national economic crime strategy, particularly with regard to technology, to be able to enhance prosecutions on that side. All of those reports have to be made to An Garda Síochána for any suspicious transactions.

Does the BPFI produce data similar to crime statistics we get in respect of the number of burglaries, detection success rates and how matters are trending? Does it have such statistics? How many of cases are solved?

The Central Bank produces an annual report that includes broad statistics. The report came out in October 2025 and showed a number of different areas and data points. For example, it revealed €160 million in fraudulent transactions in 2024. I would flag that this is 0.001% of the value of all payments. In its report, the Central Bank said that the level of fraud in Ireland is low and stabled in comparison with other countries. We do not have statistics on the reimbursement side or in respect of recoveries, as the Deputy referred to it, but we will have them under the new payment services regulation in respect of certain types of fraud.

There is a very important development that will make a very big difference on a number of fronts. Could Mr. McGuigan inform the committee about the change, because it is important for the committee to hear about it?

Under the payment services regulation, European legislators have sought to tighten up the prevention of fraud and have looked at a number of mechanisms. One of these is verification. If an online company is advertising, it needs to be a regulated provider in the EU in order to ensure that it is not just anyone uploading an advertisement online. Reports need to be generated. Financial institutions would give that data to the regulator and the regulator would publish information annually on the amount in reimbursements and the number of claims that were not reimbursed for a reason, for example, gross negligence. The regulation also contains a greater requirement to share fraud information among financial institutions and, we understand, maybe within social media companies as well in order that there is more of a cross-sectoral approach. Ms Byrne can speak to the verification of payee and the mechanism that was brought in under the instant payments regulation and has been extended within the payment services regulation to all types of credit transfers.
Verification of payee only recently came in. It is an important new addition that Ms Byrne might talk about.

The second phase of the instant payments roll-out was very successfully delivered on behalf of all the Irish banks and all the payment service providers across the EU on 9 October. It means that we can all make instant payments within ten seconds 24-7. That was a significant delivery and was very much welcomed by consumers wanting and choosing quick frictionless payments in line with consumer demand. Alongside this was introduced was a feature called verification of payee. A total of 88% of us have used Internet banking in the past year according to the Department of Finance customer sentiments survey. Everyone who is using an app, is online or is making a payment via a branch will have this additional feature, which provides greater assurance and control to people when they are making payments not just for instant payments but for regular payments. What it does is match the name a person inputs for the payment and confirms that the name held with the actual account of that-----
We have all experienced that.
That is a significant delivery, and a great additional layer of security.
It is an extra check.
Exactly.

A lot of fraud is not reported. People are embarrassed. If some guy broke into your house and stole €2,000 you had under a mattress, you would report it. If he did something online, however, you are not going to report it because you are embarrassed. There is massive underreporting.

That is true. One must have a lot of sympathy for people who go through this. There is a sense of embarrassment about it. It highlights the point we are all making about the necessity of reporting this to make sure statistics accurately reflect what is happening. It is probably inevitable, given that banking has gone online that we are seeing more instances of this. It has changed dramatically.
In a peculiar way, it is actually more painless. It is like buying something with a credit card. It is more painless than handing over €200 in notes.

We encourage people to talk about it, particularly through our FraudSMART campaign. We have seen a shift, particularly with the media reporting more on fraud, so that people are more willing to talk about it. We definitely talk about the scams but we might not be as likely to do so if we have fallen victim to one. Fraudsters are professionals. This is their full-time job so these scams are extremely sophisticated and very clever. This is not somebody chancing their arm. The scams have evolved from that. This is organised crime.
Are any of them getting caught? They do not appear on the 9 o'clock news like regular guys.

They are often prosecuted for different things. An Garda Síochána is taking prosecutions. There was a big prosecution earlier this year involving the Black Axe gang. This is all what this is funding so fraud and money laundering are connected. We have to look at the full picture. This is why it is really important to realise that this is what the fraud is funding. It is funding human trafficking, which is why we had the human trafficking campaign last week.
It is just another arm of their business.
It is.

It is also worth stating that banks are very conscious that because many people are going online, they have to put in a clunkiness sometimes that is not there. This is a clunkiness around strong customer authentication and verification of payee. Some banks impose a maximum limit for new payees on the first day.
What this is for so the customer has to tick a box.

They are conscious that because people have moved online and are using their apps. They have a responsibility to make sure that people have a second look at these things. I also know that neobanks employ this as well - having a two-minute thing, "Are you sure this is the right person you're sending it to? Do you want to think about that again?". One can use digital channels in a variety of ways to make sure one protects people and they have a responsibility to get that right.

We have had quite an interesting debate. The reason for it is because so many people have been defrauded. Many people have gone public. I understand that some do not go public. There is definitely an element of embarrassment involved, but the reality is that these people are professional scammers, they know what they are doing and they know how to scam all of us.

I am contacted more by people who have been scammed in digital banks. Digital banks play a hugely important role in our society. Loads of us have them on our phones. They are very helpful and handy, but I am generally contacted by people who have been scammed when it comes to digital banking. Do the witnesses see a difference in terms of the level of scams that happen within digital banks compared with bricks-and-mortar banks?

No, we do not see any difference. What is happening - because it is consumers rather than the banks that are being targeted - is that fraudsters are targeting consumers directly. We see approximately 80% to 90% of scams originate online. That is where the scams are happening. There is no difference. The number of attempts and the targets are no different between the neobanks or digital banks and the more traditional banks.
Can I assume, though, that the type of scam is different?

No, they are all being targeted with the same scams. Particularly in the past six months, we have seen a lot of online ads for investment scams. There has been a huge number of investment scams in the past six to 12 months. It has been growing year on year. It is the same types of scams, because consumers are being targeted by the same ones all the time. It could be text scams, online scams or emails scams, but they are primarily online scams.
Can Ms Davenport give some examples of the types of scams? Can she go into that because it would helpful?

There are a range of scams. We see banking impersonation scams, where they impersonate a bank. There are investment scams, which could be for traditional investments such as bonds, shares and such things or the scam could involve cryptocurrency as well. There are a lot of ads online for cryptocurrencies. There are romance scams, which again go across all the different banks, and text message scams.
That is a particularly personal scam about which people are less likely to come forward.

Romance scams and investment scams are the ones we need to act quickly on. To be honest, in any authorised push-payment scams - which they fall into - people need to act as quickly as possible. However, they are quite personal and take a long time. For those two scams in particular, we find it could be six months before someone makes a payment, so it is a long time before people realise they have been scammed in many of those cases. When they realise, they might not want to believe it, so they might take even more time to report what happened. That is why it is important, in any of those authorised push-payment scams but particularly investment and romance scams, that even if people have an inkling, that they come forward as quickly as possible.
Romance scams basically involve an online relationship.

They involve an online relationship, yes. There have been multiple examples over the years. They might involve companionship or a romantic relationship. It can take several months. People build up the relationship and know the person. They will ignore some of the red flags they might notice. The fraudster may not even ask for money. This is how fraudsters use manipulation tactics, and this is the social engineering we talk about in all scams. It is where all scams are going now. In people's heads they are in a committed relationship. We see things like fraudsters claiming to be having trouble getting a visa or paying for flights to come and visit the person. The fraudster does not ask for any funds, but people who are in relationships want to help and will transfer the money to do so. Those are the kinds of tactics they use for romance scams.
It is incredibly difficult.

Yes, it is incredibly difficult. It is very personal. It is definitely one that people do not want to admit to family and friends, whereas if people have bought something online with their credit cards on a dodgy website, for example, they will tell everyone about it and tell them not to use the website. There are different characteristics of various types of scams, for sure.
That is devastating.
Yes, it is heartbreaking.
I am sure it has huge implications for mental health and everything like that. I have not been contacted about those types of scams, probably because it is quite personal.

However, I have been contacted quite often when the money just comes out of the system. It happens when people are contacted by what they believe to be the bank. That is one way. There was also a scam Ms Davenport might remember, perhaps three years ago at Christmas. People gave their phone numbers when they were getting a lift and got scammed out of money that way. That was a big issue.

Recently, I was contacted by someone who lost all his savings for his house deposit. He believes he did not click on anything. It must have been something. I am not sure exactly how it happened, but there are things like that as well where people do not necessarily fall for something.

There are multiple cases - and I will not speak about any individual case - but where people do not believe they did anything, over the years we have seen cases where there might be an app they have downloaded in the background of their phones. They do not know it is tracking their behaviour on their phones, so we always tell people, for example, to make sure they download apps from official stores. There might be something on their phones that they do not realise they have downloaded and it could take weeks. It could lie dormant on the phone before people realise and they might never know that is where it came from. There are multiple ways that fraudsters can get in. It is not always by people clicking on or going into something. They are the most common ones, but late last year there was a spate of instances. One was with a photo clean up app or something to tidy up the apps on a phone, where the apps were sitting on phones in another app, so there are lots of different ways that fraudsters can get in.

The important thing is that where these happen, neobanks and traditional banks have a responsibility to take the issues and, on a case-by-case basis, look at exactly what has happened in a given scenario. The majority of banks take a common sense approach to this. If people feel they have not been properly treated as a consequence, I can assure the committee that banks spend a lot of money on complaints processes.

Only last week, we had a discussion with our member banks about the upcoming revised consumer protection code, which the deputy governor spoke about earlier in the meeting and how they are preparing for it. That discussion has happened at board level, ExCo level, first line of defence and second line of defence across the whole bank. They take these issues very seriously.

They may, but there is an issue. We have to be frank. I understand the witnesses are a representative group and will not realistically come and say, whatever their views are, but there is an issue. From the people who contact me, I know they are talking to bots and they never receive the money back. One woman lost €10,000 and never got anything back. She was hardly able to contact a person in customer service.

As an industry group, we think it is critically important that contact is made, particularly in that kind of scenario. We have said that publicly. There are two sides to every story about what has happened. We certainly cannot adjudicate on that.

I have sometimes made contact on their behalf. I will not name any names, but there have been issues. People contact me about a variety of things and ask me to help and make representations. In those instances, sometimes I get great responses, but more often than not, I do not.

The customer complaining is important because there are significant processes behind the complaints procedures. Probably some are better than others. One of the things we are conscious of as a group is to share best practice. That is why it is important that the neobanks have joined BPFI, certainly those who have authorised entities in this country, that they are part of a network and system that looks at fraud, linked to Ms Davenport's point, and that they share what they are seeing. It is really important they are part of the industry response and learn from best practice from one another. Ultimately, if a case goes before the Financial Services and Pensions Ombudsman, FSPO, it is up to him to adjudicate, but we would hope cases do not have to go to the FSPO, that they would be mediated through the bank, but each case is separate and different.

On the Deputy's point about the investment cases and the €10,000 case, I have spoken to international banks based in Dublin about people calling to their office saying they have just handed over €20,000 or €30,000 to Bank X, even though it is a wholesale, non-retail bank in Ireland. The prospectus the person got will have the bank and its CEO all over it, but it is all fraudulent and impersonated. It is an example of the lengths to which fraudsters will go to dupe people and take their money.

An important point was made about FraudSMART, that we are increasingly seeing more of our international bank colleagues join FraudSMART too, being part of it and recognising they have a role to play in this as well, particularly the larger international banks here who are well known and are being impersonated by fraudsters across the country.

Also, the evolution and customers trends, which Mr. Hayes mentioned in his opening statement, show we are a multi-bank community and 46% of Irish people have a digital bank and use it on a regular basis. From the data - and previously the Central Bank of Ireland called it out as well - there does not seem to be a difference between the providers.
It is very interesting.

Perhaps it is more about the nature of consumer trends in general. We in Ireland are digitally savvy. We have, according to the Department of Finance customer sentiment survey, a significant portion of customers who are using multiple providers. It could be more down to consumer trends.

I reiterate that in terms of the evolution of the digital journey, those interventions for a lot of providers are dynamic interventions. Customers like quick and frictionless journeys when it comes to payments, as the contactless trends clearly show. Those interventions are evolving and becoming more dynamic, depending on who you are and what you are paying for, etc. Verification of the payee helps with those types of fraud cases, including romance scams and CEO impersonation. If you are making a payment and think you are paying somebody, and the name does not match the account, you are going to think twice and, we hope, will call the bank and say you have a query. If that is identified as fraud, the bank will deal with it appropriately and notify the Garda.
That is if you can get through to someone. Some of the digital banks do not seem to be the same as bricks-and-mortar banks that you just walk into if you need to.

Our understanding, from discussions with all our members, is that they have different customer journeys in the way they manage these queries. When it escalates and becomes a fraud case, if it is determined as a fraud, there is live customer support. That is my understanding.

It is not Ms Byrne's decision so I am not casting blame. The issue is that on the one hand, we are told we need to deal with it immediately. On the other, we have a situation with some digital banks whereby you are trying to get away from the bots and find somebody live. It takes a lot of time.
Time is of the essence.

There is a timing issue. I understand that Banking and Payments Federation Ireland cannot make the decisions on behalf of these groups, but I want to make it clear that having quicker personal customer service is essential. It is a matter that we raised with representatives of the Central Bank. It seems to be an issue that the Central Bank is looking at or negotiating. That needs to be in force. A lot of money is being held in these digital banks, and money can be made out of that.
That is 100% correct. We see that in the first instance as a matter for the regulator.
Yes, of course.

If the regulator is seeing poor customer service, it is its obligation to intervene and call that out. It has a bilateral relationship with the entity concerned. Irrespective of whether it is a traditional bank or a neobank, as the Chair said, banks have been using machine learning for a very long time. They have good predictive models. If they see an amount coming out of an account at a certain time of day from a certain age cohort and going to a suspicious settlement institution, those are all red flags. I was behind the scenes and looking at some of those models. Banks are determined by models for everything, including for capital, liquidity, credit risk and everything else. The model they use to look at suspicious transactions is quite sophisticated, bank by bank, in terms of the investment made. At one level, we are seeing the outcome of the cases of the Cathaoirleach's constituents and others. Equally, the banks are stopping a lot of fraud at source by using all of the prompts. Those prompts include asking if you are sure you are sending money to the right person, if someone is pressurising you and why you are making the transaction. Those kinds of prompts that the banks make behind the scenes are preventing a lot of fraud. It is about how we develop that. To the Cathaoirleach's point, which was well made, the human interaction piece is important.

Banks take what they call the net promoter score very seriously. The net promoter score is whether you would recommend the service of a bank to your friends and family. They take that very seriously. If the net promoter score is going in the wrong direction, it is a reputational issue for the bank.
Of course.
It is an issue that is reported at board level, executive committee level and across the bank. The banks have to keep on top of the issue.

Every time I am contacted by somebody about fraud and instances where they have lost thousands of euro, I immediately put it into numerous WhatsApp groups to tell my friends not to hold money in the institution because there is concern. I tell people to be very careful about where they hold their money. Mr. Hayes is saying that no matter the institution, it seems to be a massive issue.

What he said was interesting. I understand what he means about modelling and red flags. I have noticed that for every transaction I do at the moment, I am told it is not the correct name. That is a bit concerning because the warning becomes useless.
That is the introduction of the verification of payees.
It is the law.
It is happening for every single person I transact with. Does it not then really-----
It might depend on the name the Cathaoirleach have saved for that particular payee.
I have done it wrong for everyone.

It might depend. Instead of my sister's name, I might have "sister". I might have "plumber". If I am going to send a payment, "plumber" is not going to match the actual name on the account. It might depend on what name you have saved online or on your mobile banking application for a particular payee. If it matches, it will give a match. Is it always no match?
Every single time. I do not know.
That has happened to me recently as well. Once you change it to the actual matching name-----
You will not be asked a second time.
-----you will not be asked a second time.
I am worried. I realised that I was just clicking on the "Yes" button and then thought, wait a minute-----
Any of the notifications are a matter of balance. We do not want people to start ignoring them.
Yes.

That is why there has been a change, and we will continue to see a change, to more dynamic notifications. The situation is different for the verification of a payee. That is always going to be match or no match, and if it matches, a transaction will go straight through and you will not be asked. If you are making a new payment, for example, or if a payment is in a particular amount, there will be different warnings. Every institution has its own different models, but we will see more of that coming in, over time.
If you get a no match-----
Jump out.
-----the motto is that you should verify the details via a validated source.

Banks have their own internal mechanisms and all of that. I was contacted by one woman. I was going to say "correct me if I am wrong", but the witnesses do not know the situation. I recall that she had done a transaction and got a call from the bank to say there was an issue and she needed to transfer the money back in a particular way. In fact, it was the fraud worsening and she lost even more money.

That is a common development we have seen in scams. You may get a text message. There have been fewer of them since the ComReg initiative and we should see fewer such examples. It is where you get a text message and click on a link. What you have actually done is put in information. For example, if you were to get a text message with a customs charge of €3.50, it is not the €3.50 they are looking for. When you click on that link, they are looking for your name, address and telephone number. The information you are giving out is giving them more information. They then call and ask if they are taking to, for example, Niamh Davenport. This is the social engineering piece that is luring you into the scam and making you believe that who you are talking to is who they say they are, which is not the case. They layer it. This is the sophistication we have see develop over recent years.
They have people doing it.
Yes.
It must be big business.
It is big business. People are being recruited into it unwillingly in many countries. This is happening overseas-----
I heard that.
-----where people are being held against their will and made to perform these scams on a daily basis.

If they send out 1 million texts, they are looking for just one or two responses. Then they are quids in. If you speak to An Garda Síochána or any of the banks around this, it is all done outside the country ostensibly. Some of it is in the country but the majority is outside the country. They are just funnelling the numbers through.
I had heard of that. There is a human trafficking element that the witnesses are saying is funding-----

Yes. We launched a campaign on human trafficking last week. Human trafficking, or modern day slavery, is in every town around Ireland. We launched a campaign for consumers to understand and notify where there are red flags around human trafficking in Ireland. It is happening in other countries. The people who are making these calls do not necessarily want to be a part of the scam.
They are being held against their will. Their passports have been taken and they are being held in what are unofficially known as hotels, but they are far from being hotels.
I thank Ms Davenport.

I will just add to that in regard to some of the changes at European level being looked at prevention. A lot of the good work that ComReg does involves stopping those texts, but some of the higher value scams originate on social media and such platforms. We have been strongly advocating that social media or these companies, be it Google or whichever of them, would require that they would only accept ads from regulated financial service providers. We will have seen many of the examples where Irish politicians have been impersonated, etc. The tactic used is to get people offline. People click on the ad, give their information to invest in a government bond, for example, which might say it will give people a 5% return. People think that 5% is legitimate, but what the scammers really want are their details. Going forward, hopefully, this should be prevented with these changes at a European level, or at least the onslaught of these types of ads people are getting on certain platforms.

We started this work 18 months ago on trying to lobby for that aspect to go into the new payments services regulation. It has started. We should flag that Ireland is slightly ahead in the sense that Google implemented it here a year ago. From a Google perspective, we are one of six countries, I think, to have this in. It is not across all social media, but this regulation will bring it across all technology platforms. It is a huge change.

I had to pay the M50 toll today. If I google "M50 toll", my worry is always what if there is a scam that comes up first and I end up putting in all my details. Are there protections against this happening?

The payments services regulation is focused solely on financial institutions and ads for financial services. It is to stop those banking impersonation scams in particular. I would not see that people would be getting one specifically on a toll road.
It might be when stopping or whatever it might be.
I know what the Cathaoirleach is saying.
It should say it on the website.
Okay.

I will also use this as an opportunity to say we have scamchecker.ie. It was mentioned in the statement that we launched this last year. People can go onto that website, put in any URL and it will help in verifying whether it is a real one or not.
That is all from me. I call an Teachta Timmins.
I have a few quick questions. Ms Gill spoke about instant payments and ten seconds. To use that dreadful phrase, though, when it is gone, it is gone and the money cannot come back. Is this the case?

We go back to the focus needing to be on prevention, and you have the interventions. Does the risk profile change when it is an instant payment? Naturally, it does because the money lands into the account within ten seconds and if a fraudster is on top of it, they will move the money out.
Does the bank take it back before the fraudster uses it?
If the fraudster is on top of it and the bank does not know about it, he or she has the potential to take it out within the ten seconds. The risk profile does change.
Can the bank take it back if it gets to it first?

It depends on where the funds go to. It does make it more challenging. That is totally a fair point. The risk profile does change in that it does heighten it. I suppose that is why when instant payments were rolled out, very intentionally verification of payee for instant payments and regular transfers was rolled out too to try to protect people or add an additional layer of security and greater assurance that the right person was being paid.

Going back to the people issue again, I know we have probably thrashed it to death at this stage, but it is part of the customer service requirement to have a voice at the end of the phone. There is that comfort. It is like seeing gardaí on the beat. It does not have any impact but there is the comfort of having customer service confidence in the system. That is the benefit of it.

People have moved from bank branches, though not exclusively. Our pillar banks argue heavily that it is important for them as part of their competitive edge to have branches around the country in terms of-----
To meet a person walking in the door.

Yes. There is a different model for neobanks, though, because they do not have branches and operate through quite a slick platform. If they were here, they would make the point that they escalate to that live conversation and potentially to where that in-app call that is made. Ultimately, the question is whether this is sufficient for people who are in the middle of that very stressful situation. This is an issue they will address. Ultimately, though, it is that escalation point that is important because it can solve it.

I have one final comment. I worked with a company a few years ago and we had an American bank. We had an operation in America and it was controlled from Ireland. I was controlling the bank account. If I did a transfer over $5,000 or $10,000 to pay an American supplier, for example, I got a phone call within a few minutes from the American bank asking me if I had put the transfer through before it was authorised. The voice does give confidence.

I fully accept that. Each bank has its own policy in this regard, but especially for the more traditional banks, but also for the neobanks, if a new payee is being created, there is a maximum amount a person can send in one day. They argue that having that limitation is a good thing. It might be frustrating for us because we cannot get the full amount to someone. The banks, though, argue that is a good thing because it creates a bit of friction in the system to slow things down. If they were here, bank representatives would say that for them it is an important additional protection they have introduced.
In the app, it is only possible to transfer something like €1,000 a day. If I log into the online banking, though, it is possible to transfer much more through that fail-safe system.

As much as consumers want frictionless fast payments, we would be looking to maybe go the opposite way sometimes from the perspective of financial crime. Those controls are there to protect consumers.
I agree with Ms Davenport.

From a fraud perspective, whether it is a digital bank or one of the traditional banks, we tell people to make sure they are flagging that a call is about fraud. It is important for people to say why they are ringing and to get through to the right section. From the digital perspective, for fraud, live calls available are in-app, so it is important to note that difference.
That is good. It is too easy to pay. That is the bottom line.
Yes, it is.
We need to make it more painful.

I am not sure that should be the Deputy's election line. Go raibh maith agaibh. I thank all the witnesses for coming in front of the committee. It has been quite interesting and eye-opening. I thank members for participating in today's meeting.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 5.57 p.m. until 3.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 10 December 2025.
